Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020: Vibrio Cholerae: An old disease with new tricks
Award.AbstractNarration: This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology. The fellowship supports a research and training plan for the Fellow that will increase the participation of groups underrepresented in biology. The objective of this study is to understand the role that wild birds play in transmitting Vibrio cholerae, the bacterial species that causes cholera. Vibrio cholerae is one of the most important human pathogens, however little is known concerning how V. cholerae interacts with its environment outside of the human host, specifically how, and when, it infects other species. Traditionally, studies on V. cholerae have focused on how it causes disease in humans, however there is growing evidence that V. cholerae are able to infect waterfowl, and that waterfowl species may be capable of transmitting the bacteria. This study will examine whether waterfowl are ‘competent’ hosts for V. cholerae, e.g. whether V. cholerae is simply consumed by waterfowl and the infection is transient, or whether V. cholerae is now becoming a natural part of the intestinal bacterial community in avian species. In addition, this study will examine the evolutionary strategies that bacterial species, such as V. cholerae, use in adapting or re-adapting to new hosts. In addition to this research, the fellow will promote the greater inclusion of diverse and under-represented groups through the hands-on mentorship, career development, and educational support while performing research at Yale University and at the University of Central Florida. <br/><br/>Vibrio cholerae remains one of the most prominent pathogens in human history. Recent findings suggest birds are playing an increasing role in the dissemination of the pathogen. However, whether this represents an unexplored pathway of pathogen mobility, or bacterial re-emergence into a host-pathogen system, .e.g. waterfowl, is yet to be determined. The fellow will investigate how interactions between this opportunistic microbe and anthropogenic processes influence pathogen re-emergence within a natural avian system. Specifically, this study will focus on free-ranging, peridomestic Mallards naturally exposed to V. cholerae among anthropogenically associated aquatic habitats of eastern Florida. Given the rising incidence of isolates from birds, the warming Gulf coast, and the paucity of human hosts, it is expected that V. cholerae are now alternatively colonizing southeastern U.S. waterfowl. Through this research, the fellow also seeks to continue a model of outreach both at Yale and at UCF, through additional personnel funding acquired to provide research opportunities for under-represented groups at both universities. The fellow will also increase outreach to community college students, who have the fewest opportunities to integrate research into their studies.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Award Title: Vibrio Cholerae: An old disease with new tricks.

Director/PI: Andrea J. Ayala.

Federal Award ID: 1208831

In 2020, Andrea J. Ayala received a 3-year, 207,000-dollar postdoctoral fellowship award, specifically, an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Broadening Participation of Groups Under-represented in Biology, entitled, “Vibrio Cholerae: An old disease with new tricks.”  The purpose of this project was to identify whether waterfowl, specifically Mottled Ducks (Anas fulvigula) and Mottled Duck hybrids were harboring and shedding Vibrio cholerae O1, the pathogen responsible for the disease cholera, in Florida’s urban waterways. Preliminary data performed at the University of Central Florida during the fellowship period suggests that Vibrio cholera O1 is not found in the aquatic environments of Florida.  However, preliminary data found that a high prevalence of the approximately 100 ducks that were captured and sampled served as competent reservoirs for other Vibrio species of public health concern, such as Vibrio cholerae non-O1, Vibrio parahaemolyticus, Vibrio vulnificus, and Vibrio vulnificus.  Sequencing results are pending, which will provide the team with a complete picture of the public health implications of the Vibrio species that were isolated from the captured ducks. To determine whether the ducks were competent reservoirs of the bacteria, the team collected blood in addition to fecal samples, and the preliminary data suggests that the captured ducks were healthy, such that the ducks could potentially transport these Vibrio species from one water source to another without ill effects.  The team also looked at lead levels in relation to the number of Vibrio species that the captured birds were shedding, these results are also pending.  However, they are important as limited liver function, which is associated with lead toxicosis, is associated with poor outcomes of a Vibrio infection in human hosts. 

The most important part of the project was the involvement of students from Valencia College and the University of Central Florida, with both institutions serving as Hispanic Serving Institutions. The team was able to provide experiential learning experiences for over 40 undergraduate students and graduate students who demonstrated interest in the fields of ornithology and disease ecology, with approximately 80% of the students serving as underrepresented students in STEM. They learned to capture and humanely handle ducks, the correct baiting protocol for capture, and how to identify different species of waterfowl. The team is still working hand in hand with these students, in the culture and sequencing portion of the project. As a result of this project, the students involved in the research are actively considering graduate school in a number of STEM fields: bioinformatics, population genetics, pollination ecology, bacteriology, microbiology, and ornithology.  They are also serving as co-authors on four manuscripts in progress, and served as co-authors on two presentations, one which was given at Yale University.
